# FOSS Licensing

A Historical Perspective

## In the beginning... {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**Software was free**

- 1950s-1970s: Software bundled with hardware
- Source code shared freely among researchers
- Collaboration was the norm

![](https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/2942/2942156.png){width="200" fig-alt="Collaboration icon"}

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**Then came commercialization**

- Late 1970s-1980s: Software became a product
- Companies realized revenue potential
- Proprietary licenses became standard
- Source code became trade secret

![](https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/3135/3135706.png){width="200" fig-alt="Business revenue icon"}

:::

::::

## What are software licenses? {.smaller}

::: {style="display: flex; gap: 20px; align-items: center;"}

::: {style="flex: 0 0 65%;"}

Different aspects of software are protected by different types of intellectual property law.

```{mermaid}

    style Patent fill:#3a3a3a,stroke:#666666,color:#888888

```

:::

::: {style="flex: 0 0 35%; text-align: center;"}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 20px; border-radius: 15px; margin-bottom: 15px; border: 2px solid #8be9fd; color: #f8f8f2; font-size: 0.85em; text-align: center;"}

**A software license is a legal instrument** governing the use, modification, and distribution of software.

:::

![](media/laurent.jpg){width="250" fig-alt="Laurent illustration"}

:::

:::

## Movements ↔ Licence Philosophies {.smaller}

|                     | **Reciprocal (Copyleft)**                  | **Permissive**                          |
|---------------------|--------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------|
| **Origin**          | Free Software Movement                     | Open Source Initiative                  |
| **Philosophy**      | Preserve freedom for all users             | Maximum freedom to developers           |
| **Key Feature**     | Derivatives must use same license          | Minimal restrictions                    |
| **Examples**        | GPL, AGPL, MPL                             | MIT, BSD, Apache                        |
| **Goal**            | Ensure software remains free               | Enable broad adoption and use           |

## Effects on derivative work {.smaller}

**Derivative work** includes modifications, extensions, and in some cases, linking to the original software.

::: {style="display: flex; gap: 20px;"}

::: {.fragment style="flex: 1; background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #8be9fd; color: #f8f8f2; text-align: center;"}

::: {style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;"}
GPL-2 (Reciprocal)
:::

![](https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/1161/1161388.png){width="120" fig-alt="Chain link icon" style="display: block; margin: 0 auto;"}

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em; margin-top: 10px; text-align: left;"}

**Derivative work restrictions:**

- Modified code → Must be GPL-2
- Linked libraries → Must be GPL-2
- Combined works → Must be GPL-2
- Source code must be disclosed

:::

:::

::: {.fragment style="flex: 1; background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #bd93f9; color: #f8f8f2; text-align: center;"}

::: {style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;"}
MIT (Permissive)
:::

![](https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/3004/3004458.png){width="120" fig-alt="Open hands icon" style="display: block; margin: 0 auto;"}

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em; margin-top: 10px; text-align: left;"}

**Derivative work freedom:**

- Modified code → Any license
- Linked libraries → Any license
- Combined works → Any license
- Source code disclosure optional

:::

:::

:::

# Legal Aspects

## When do licenses matter? {.smaller}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 20px; border-radius: 15px; margin: 15px 0; text-align: center; font-size: 1.1em; border: 2px solid #ffb86c; color: #f8f8f2;"}

License obligations are triggered by **distribution**

:::

. . .

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; margin: 15px 0; text-align: center; border: 2px solid #50fa7b; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**Internal use** within your organization is generally **NOT** distribution

:::

. . . 

**Examples:**

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**IS distribution:**

- Embedded imaging software in microscopes shipped to customers
- Control software bundled with semiconductor lithography systems
- Lens design software provided to opticians and eye care professionals

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**NOT distribution:**

- Internal software tools for microscope development and testing
- Web services running on internal servers for quality assurance
- Software prototypes used only within internal R&D labs

:::

::::

# Enterprise Risks

## Lack of awareness and compliance {.smaller}

::: {style="display: flex; gap: 20px;"}

::: {.fragment style="flex: 1; background-color: #44475a; padding: 12px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #ffb86c; color: #f8f8f2; font-size: 0.8em;"}

**Common issues:**

- Developers add dependencies unknowingly
- Transitive dependencies go unnoticed
- License obligations misunderstood
- No inventory of FOSS components

:::

::: {.fragment style="flex: 1; background-color: #44475a; padding: 12px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #ff5555; color: #f8f8f2; font-size: 0.8em;"}

**Non-compliance consequences:**

- Copyright infringement lawsuits
- Forced source code disclosure
- Injunctions preventing product sales
- Reputational damage
- Financial penalties

:::

:::

<br>

. . .

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #bd93f9; color: #f8f8f2; font-size: 0.85em;"}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="70%"}

**License changes can break your business:**

In 2024, Redis changed from BSD (permissive) to dual-license (SSPL/RSALv2), restricting commercial use. Companies relying on Redis had to either pay for commercial licenses or migrate to alternatives

**Lesson:** Monitor upstream license changes actively!

:::

::: {.column width="30%"}

![](media/redis.jpg){width="250" fig-alt="Redis logo"}

:::

## Security vulnerabilities {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%" .fragment}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; margin-bottom: 15px; border: 2px solid #ff5555; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**Common security risks:**

- Outdated packages with known CVEs
- Unpatched critical vulnerabilities
- Supply chain attacks

:::

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #ffb86c; color: #f8f8f2; font-size: 0.8em;"}

**CVEs can enable:**

- **Remote Code Execution** - Attacker runs arbitrary code on your servers
- **Data Exfiltration** - Unauthorized access to sensitive information
- **Denial of Service** - System crashes or becomes unavailable

:::

# Automated Tools

## Why automate FOSS management? {.smaller}

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}

| **Problem** | **How Automation Helps** |
|-------------|--------------------------|
| Hundreds to thousands of direct dependencies | **Automated discovery** of all FOSS components in codebase |
| Tens of thousands of transitive dependencies | **Dependency mapping** to track entire dependency tree |
| Multiple package managers (npm, pip, Maven, etc.) | **Multi-ecosystem support** across all package managers |
| Constantly evolving vulnerability landscape | **Continuous monitoring** for newly discovered CVEs |
| Unknown license obligations | **License detection** and compliance checking |
| No visibility into component inventory | **SBOM generation** (Software Bill of Materials) |
| Manual tracking doesn't scale | **Automated alerts** and reporting for issues |

:::

## Open Source Tool: Trivy {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="70%"}

**[Trivy](https://trivy.dev/)** - Comprehensive security scanner by Aqua Security

- Vulnerability detection
- License scanning
- Secret detection
- SBOM generation

**Scan a container image:**

```bash
trivy image nginx:latest
```

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em; margin-top: 10px; font-style: italic;"}
Free, open-source, widely adopted in CI/CD pipelines
:::

## Integrating tools into your workflow {.smaller}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px 0; font-size: 0.9em; border: 2px solid #50fa7b; color: #f8f8f2;"}

- **Scan early and often** - Integrate into CI/CD pipeline
- **Set clear policies** - Define acceptable risk levels
- **Automate fixes** - Use dependency update tools (Dependabot, Renovate)
- **Monitor continuously** - New vulnerabilities discovered daily
- **Educate developers** - Make security everyone's responsibility

:::

```{mermaid}
%%| eval: true
%%| echo: false
flowchart LR
    A[Developer commits] --> B[CI/CD Pipeline]
    B --> C[FOSS Scanner]
    C --> D{Vulnerabilities?}
    D -->|Yes| E[Block/Alert]
    D -->|No| F[Deploy]
    E --> G[Create ticket]
    G --> H[Developer fixes]
    H --> A

    style C fill:#e3f2fd
    style E fill:#ffebee
    style F fill:#e8f5e9
```
